job_title: Student Facilities Assistant in Highland Heights, KY

job_title: Admissions in Highland Heights, Campbell, KY
pros: Lower management and peers are great. Being able to work with students are great. This office used to be so fulfilling and but things have changed. Tuition waiver for staff is the one big reason people stay but once they graduate they leave.
cons: Incredibly insulting pay. Higher management is now in panic mode due to the financial issues of the university caused by poor decision making from previous higher management that have since left the university. Current higher management is now stressed trying to fix the problems and to cover their own, blaming admissions for not bringing in enough students when the reality is there was not a smart financial plan set in action for the last few years of the university. Staff members take advantage of the food pantry on campus because pay is not livable. Higher management thinks they are doing us well by coming into meetings to tell us how important we are to the university and how we are "worth our weight in gold" but then they shift the blame to us and ignore our requests to evaluate our pay scale. We are expected to do so much, processors process for almost every student, each department demands that they are prioritized, and make some of the worst pay in the office. Over worked with very little support and even less pay. (If you haven't caught on yet, the pay is not worth it) Higher management is absolutely clueless on what we do. Yet they come in with these grand ideas on how to "fix" things and act surprise when we tell them the obstacles we face in implementing them. The micromanaging along with them not knowing what the day to day responsibilities of our office makes the day-to-day stressful. Higher management doesn't listen to anything we have to say. Cross training and communication between departments is basically non-existing. That's why no one knows what we do. Staff finds out information about the university from news not from the university. NKU isnt the job force it used to be.

review_title: Great place to work. Very friendly and lots of opportunities

review_title: Great place if you love aawful pay and worse admin
job_title: Laboratory Technician in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Technical staff stick together and work hard, you'll get to work with some spectacular undergraduates, and some great professors...unfortunately. I was paid more than that salary only due to the lab manager I was hired under pushing for my Masters (part of the job listing) to count toward my higher pay grade.
cons: I was interviewed the day after a hiree who lasted a week put her keys on the lab managers desk and walked out due to the blatantly disrespectful way a Microbiology professor spoke to her. Should have been a clue. Hey! Are you comfortable working with cadavers? I HOPE SO! Because they will NOT tell you in the interview as a Bio tech you may need to flip or attend to the cadavers used for advanced anatomy. Biology department heads swing wildly between "I hate this job and will refuse to do anything confrontational, allow professors to treat technicians like grad students or street dogs they can kick when frustrated" and "Dolores Umbridge." If you work here as a lab tech, be prepared to draw HARD boundaries about work life balance and NEVER work when they aren't paying you. You'll bank over time, but they'll only offer you time off reciprocity but never a single red cent. Profs will blame LITERALLY every mistake even those you FILM THEM MAKING on tech staff, and seem allergic to taking responsibility. I had to record lab meetings to play back due to a faculty preference for gaslighting. If you do take this position, I recommend you proceed with caution and the awareness that Kentucky is a one party recording state.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Highland Heights, Campbell, KY

cons: Low pay Department budget cuts and shrinking

job_title: Director of Development in Cincinnati, OH
pros: NKU has a lot of amazing people on staff, especially for the advancement team. The Deans are all fantastic to work with, though they can be slightly reluctant to collaborate outside of their colleges. And the systems in place to help you do your job are really fantastic. There's a lot of flexibility around your weekly schedule and the benefits are great.
cons: What you start with is all you get. I was made a lot of promises about growth opportunity when I took the job, but none of that ever came to fruition. I never received a single pay raise, was told no regarding most professional development opportunities, and would have the credit for much of my work taken from me. My responsibilities increased exponentially, but my compensation and recognition never increased. The team is encouraged to be competitive with each other, which inspires a tone of distrust among the other gift officers.

review_title: Hard Times, Poor Leadership, No Transparency or Trust
job_title: Associate Professor in Union, KY
pros: The students are amazing, with most working full time and supporting families while pursuing their college degrees.
cons: Historically underfunded since its beginning, NKU continues to suffer unconscionable cuts to its budget every year.  The relatively new and inexperienced administration has consistently received abysmal evaluations from faculty and staff (every one receiving less than a 2.0 on a 5.0 scale, which was discovered after a FOIA request by faculty), is not interested in learning about the history and culture of the university, fails to provide any guidance to those eager to learn new strategies for improving the university, has mishandled serious incidents on campus (even being reprimanded by a judge for falsely stating a gun a student attempted to fire at another student on campus was "inoperable"), and has been caught in numerous false or, at best, deceptive statements to the Faculty Senate.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Highland Heights, KY
pros: Calm work environment, nice employee perks (class hours for example), well positioned for travel to and from (right near two major highways), and as it grows, there is an ever-changing staff environment from year to year.
cons: It's a university--filled with departmental politics which even the staff get dragged into, constantly suffering entropy due to a large nefarious student population, and the bureaucracy is a thing of legend. Even the students realize how bad it can be to get paperwork from one end of the university to the other, which is even worse for employees because the paperwork has to travel up the hierarchy, across to another department, then upward again, and you might see a resolution... eventually. Budget season is especially stressful.

review_title: Great Benefits, but experience only pays if you leave....
job_title: Assistant Director in Highland Heights, KY
pros: Lots of paid time off - 20 vacation days per year and roughly 12 sick days. Also, you get 2-3 paid days at Thanksgiving and 5 paid days around Christmas. Also tuition assistance of 6 credit hours per semester for yourself and nuclear family.
cons:
1 university-wide pay raise in the past 5 years, and it was only 1.5%. 

Jobs can be "upgraded" as you take on more responsibilities, but this does not work to your favor. If your job is "upgraded" you receive a 4% raise for every grade level raised (university policy). However, if you were to leave and your job is posted, someone else could be hired in making 15-20% more than you. This policy creates low morale. Workers aren't willing to take on more responsibility and learn more since the pay increase is insignificant for the additional work you have to complete.

No real professional development opportunities (other than going back to school).

Employees have to pay to park (around $345 a year).

job_title: Campus Recreation Employee in Highland Heights, Campbell, KY
pros:
Most coworkers are good friends, all are at least friendly to each other. 
All workers are in college, so everyone is around the same age and sharing similar experiences. 
Chance to get to know other students that come in to work out.
cons:
Only feedback is negative.
Bosses like to make you feel incompetent, even if that means talking about your faults to or in front of your coworkers and patrons. 
Bosses punish people who get to be too good of friends by separating them on the schedule. 
Bosses have often threatened to fire entire staff and hire all new, because we're "expendable."

job_title: Assistant Professor in Highland Heights, Campbell, KY
pros: Working 10 months per year and having 2 months off during the summer as faculty. State retirement, tuition benefit, and vacation time allotted are pros of the faculty position. The people I worked with were delightful.
cons: A bureaucratic mess! The Dean was a horrible and narcissistic and did nothing but criticize faculty. Workload was completely unreasonable. Pay was ridiculously inadequate. My salary increased by 40% when I left and took another faculty position at a different university.

job_title: Anonymous in Highland Heights, KY
pros:
Benefits: progress has been made in recent years in terms of insurance coverage for extended family members, and the tuition waiver and health center benefits are nice.

Physical Environment: the campus has seen dramatic improvement in physical facilities over the past several years, and has definitely outgrown the "concrete jungle" reputation it had in the past. Thanks to new buildings like the Science Center, Student Union and Griffin Hall, as well as renovations like the University Center, main campus plaza, and Loch Norse, NKU is much more visually appealing and attractive.
cons:
Morale: after many years of budget cuts and becoming increasingly "lean" in staffing (translation: employees are expected to do more work in the same amount of time, with less funding and nearly zero increase in compensation). Lack of ability to trust supervisors, HR staff, and other leadership leaves NKU employees afraid to do anything but "keep their heads down" and try to avoid being the next one on the layoff list.

Salary/Wages: Changes in the upper administration, including the creation of VP positions of higher levels (and, presumably, pay) than existed in the past and addition of at least one "special advisor" position, give the appearance (without a transparent explanation to demonstrate otherwise) that it's okay for leaders to compensate themselves well, but lower-level employees and positions are not a priority.

review_title: Great, talented people - colleagues and students alike.
job_title: in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Great people- colleagues and students alike. Houses a lot of talent. Beautiful campus. I really liked the on-site early childhood center and health and wellness programs as well. Good benefits.
cons: Not always the best work/life balance- but it depends on your department. It seemed like quite a few employees were on contract and may be subject to cuts based on funding/budget. No raises for the last couple years due to budget cuts which can equal low morale and a slight disconnect from the community.

-Temporary (If they like you, might ask you to stay on for a longer appointment)

cons: There are No pay raises and no incentives for employees to do well at their jobs.  They may cut the state pension plan which many people continue working here for.

review_title: Overall, my experience has been good; inconsistent leadership is chaotic.
